news politics -mini-budget-graphs-expose-"Spring Statement: Rishi Sunaks announcements explainedByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Rishi Sunak’s Spring Statement has been blown apart by experts who warn .million Brits - including half a million children - will be plunged into poverty.Every Budget event starts with a preening Chancellor and ends with expert complaints. But what sets this one apart is the sheer scale of the crisis hitting Brits. whose disposable incomes will see the sharpest fall since records began in . The millionaire Chancellor promised to help families with skyrocketing prices through a p fuel duty cut now, and a big rise in National Insurance thresholds in July.It’s £bn of tax cuts - but analysis shows it’s a drop in the ocean, as inflation soars close to % and the tax burden still rises overall between now and . The Resolution Foundation also slammed the Chancellor for giving £ out of every £ to the wealthier half, as there’s no new increase to benefits or cash help for energy bills. With UK inflation soaring to .% - its fastest rise in  years - millions of households will be worrying about their own finances. The  cost of living crisis is hitting energy prices, fuel and the cost of food, with the governmentaposs only solution so far to offer all households a £ loan to help pay off their energy bills - which must be paid back eventually. Chancellor Rishi Sunakaposs Spring Statement saw him announce a cut in fuel duty, although this will cost the Treasury billions without putting cash back in familiesapos pockets. So how will the Spring Statement affect you The  huge big cost of living blows hitting you from next Friday What the fuel duty cut actually means - and whether weaposll see the dference in our pockets The Spring Statement  summaryaposs key announcements Everything you need to know about the National Insurance cut The UKaposs current inflation rate amid the Spring Statement - as Brits are left with crippling costsKeep up with live announcements from the Statement in the Mirroraposs live blogIf you need help with the cost of living crisis, weaposve put together a list of charities and schemes offering advice and grants to keep you and your family warm and fed this year. Boris Johnson said “it will continue to be tough, it will continue to be chippy, but we will get through it and we will look after people throughout”.But what do the charts from his own Treasury, watchdogs, and independent think tanks say  We’ve taken a look at  that highlight the enormity of the problems facing the economy... Inflation is rocketing to a -year high  Inflation is due to rocket to .% on average in   and could peak at nearly %. The Office for Budget Responsibility said the rise “will erode real incomes and consumption”, slashing GDP growth from a % forecast to .% this year. This graph highlights just how steeply inflation has climbedbeyond what experts thought it would hit five months ago , due to the Ukraine-Russia war. This will be the highest inflation in the history of the OBR, which was set up in .  This graph from the Office for Budget Responsibility shows the same inflation data but going back to . It shows inflation will peak above the .% it hit in  andto levels not seen since the early s. Disposable incomes will suffer the biggest drop since the s - at least  Brits’ household disposable incomes per person will fall .% in real terms in -, due to inflation outstripping wages. That is the biggest fall in a single year since records began in . And this is even after factoring in £ support for energy bills, the temporary cut in fuel duty and rise in National Insurance thresholds. The Office for Budget Responsibility said this help announced since October has offset around a third of the fall in living standards.  This Office for Budget Responsibility graph is an even starker way of portraying the same data. It shows disposable incomes only fell in real terms in nine years since the s - four of them since the Tories took power in . And the fall projected for - is by far the deepest, outstripping those in the s or the wake of the  financial crash. Wages are now £k lower than without the  crash  This shocking chart on wages from the Institute for Fiscal Studies shows the same problem in the starkest way yet. The experts warned wages are now £, lower than what they could have beenthe trend of - had continued. The financial crash of  still cases a long shadow over politics today. The national debt wasnapost cut by the Tories This chart from the Treasury explodes the myth that the Tories brought down ‘ Labour ’s debt’ from the financial crash with austerity.Net debt shot up due to the bank bailouts and other measures of , but has continued rising since and spiked again due to Covid. It is still predicted to be .% of the UK’s entire GDP in . And the cost of servicing that debt rockets as inflation rises. Since the last forecast, the cost of servicing the national debt has risen by more than £billion in - alone.  This chart shows the same data but with a longer timescale, showing how debt was more than double Britain’s GDP after the Second World War - but fell steadily as the decades rolled on. That falling of debt continued through the s and stayed low until the financial crash. It jumped, then climbed further under the Tories. Rishi Sunakaposs new apostax cutsapos do exist - but overall itaposs still a tax hike  Rishi Sunak boasted he’d become the tax-cutting Chancellor with cuts to National Insurance, fuel duty and a p income tax cut from April .But the IFS think tank has warned the tax burden will in fact be rising, not falling, overall because frozen thresholds will drag .million more people into paying income tax. In this chart, the Office for Budget Responsibility finds the Chancellor’s tax cuts barely make a dent in all the tax rises that have been announced in . The OBR found previously announced tax rises will add .% of GDP to the tax burden - already the highest in decades - by  . The freeze on fuel duty, change to National Insurance and p income tax cut in  will lower that tax burden by just .%.  This is a dferent way of looking at the same information on tax. In this chart, the Institute for Fiscal Studies shows how ‘Illusionist’ Rishi Sunak is in fact raising taxes on Brits - not cutting them. A median earner on £, will be £ worse off in   than   - a £k earner will be nearly £ worse off. Boris Johnson claimed the Chancellor had “cut taxes for working people by, I think, the biggest single amount for the last  years.” The IFS said this is technically true. But IFS Director Paul Johnson said: “He can now expect to raise more in tax as a share of national income by  than he expected last October. In fact, taxes are set to rise to their highest level as a fraction of national income since Clement Attlee was prime minister.”  This graph shows just how fast the tax burden has shot up to a record high since Covid. The OBR warns the tax burden overall will reach .% of GDP in - - the highest level since the late s. That’s up from % of GDP in -. It’s fuelled by rising National Insurance but also in frozen thresholds in income tax until . title: how rishi sunak went dishy
story: How Rishi Sunak went from Dishy Rishi to out-of-touch Tory Drippy SunakThe telegenic Chancellor was praised for the generosity of the furlough scheme and his slick performances at the Covid press conferences - but Rishi Sunak is now discovering that popularity can be as superficial as the images on his Instagram account Image: SIMON WALKER HM TreasuryAnalysisByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Mar |commentsA few months ago Rishi Sunak was the toast of the Conservative Party. The telegenic Chancellor was praised for the generosity of the furlough scheme and his slick performances at the Covid press conferences. Sunak is now discovering that popularity can be as superficial as the images on his Instagram account. His Spring Statement did not just land badly, it belly-flopped. There was nothing extra to help people with the cost of living, an additional .million people will be dragged into poverty and workers are going to be hit with higher taxes. Those who had shares in Sunak are now trying to offload them before then reach the status of a Russian rouble. The fall in Sunak’s stock seems to have happened overnight. But the Chancellor’s downfall has been in the making ever since he stepped into Number . He was presented by his slick PR machine as a slightly nerdy guy who wears a hoodie to work, has a nice haircut and wouldn’t offend your motheryou brought him round to dinner.  He was a safe pair of hands whose grasp of detail and measured manner offered a reassuring contrast to the bumbling, chaotic style of Boris Johnson. That’s what made him an appealing prospect for many voters - especially moderate conservatives - as a potential future leader. But beneath the soft-speaking and cosy leisurewear was a Thatcherite Tory, whose privileged upbringing, private education and vast family wealth has apparently left him struggling to understand the real world.For example, the Government was today forced to admit the Chancellor had borrowed a Kia Rio from a Sainsbury’s garage employee for a staged photo of him filling up with petrol with a broad grin. Downing Street said he paid for the petrol himself. In an interview yesterday morning, Mr Sunak said the food item where he’d most notice a price increase was bread, because “we have all dferent breads in my house.” The gaffe led to him being branded “Rishi Antoinette” on Twitter.  And the same day, footage emerged of Mr Sunak apparently struggling to pay for a tiny can of Coca-Cola in a shop, because he kept trying to tap his contactless card on the bar code reader. He once in an interview described himself as a “massive Coke addict” - which he quickly claried, meant the drink. But he also revealed he was a cola snob, and prefers the formula only available by importing bottles from Mexico. He won’t touch the Diet or Zero ieties. Evidence of his expensive tastes doesn’t end there.  Photos ahead of his first budget in March  saw him pose up with a £ bluetooth coffee mug, which can be temperature controlled from an app on his phone. It’s been claimed the Chancellor’s favourite snack is a truffle-flavoured crisp made by Torres, which costs as much as £ a bag from posh department store Fortnum and Mason’s.  In pictures released before his  budget in October, the Chancellor was shown wearing £ designer flip flops made by LA brand Palm Angels and sold in Selfridge’s. And he revealed in  that he starts the day with a ride on his £, Peloton exercise bike, where he enjoys online classes hosted by Instagram-friendly New York trainer Cody Rigsby.  In December , just days after freezing public sector pay for millions of workers, the Mirror revealed he had dined with his we, Akshata Murthy, at Mayfairaposs  Hertford Street - known as Londonaposs most secretive private membersapos club. The Mirror understands Mrs Murthy - whose vast wealth reportedly puts her higher up the rich list than the Queen - planned to hold a surprise party for Mr Sunak’s th birthday at the same private club in , but Covid- restrictions got in the way. Mrs Murthy’s business interests came under the spotlight today amid questions about whether Mr Sunak’s family had benefited from interests in Russia.  Mr Sunak was forced to deny profiting from Vladimir Putin’s regime, after being asked about Mrs Murthy’s reported stake in Infosys, an IT firm founded by her billionaire father N.R. Narayana Murthy. Just last week, Mr Sunak warned businesses to “think carefully” about making investments in Russia. But unlike other ministers, Mr Sunak has resisted calls to declare his we’s shareholdings on the Register of Members’ Interests. He insists he “followed the ministerial code to the letter.”  And Mr Sunak’s decision making was called into question long before his failure to deliver help for working families in Wednesday’s mini-Budget. Analysis found his “Eat Out to Help Out” campaign failed to deliver a long-term boost to struggling restaurants and cafes, knocked sideways by the pandemic. Studies did suggest, however, that it helped to push up infections - with the scheme linked to a spike of between  and %. Will Sunak be able to ride the wave of unpopularity or will he turn out to be yet another politician who believed his own publicity  Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON SainsburysInfosysMayfair Ltd.Conservative PartyThe Coca-Cola CompanyBoris JohnsonVladimir PutinSpring StatementAppsFoodFitnessPoliticsBillionairesRishi Sunak" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news politics poor-pay-price-again-sunaks-"Spring Statement: Rishi Sunaks announcements explainedopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Mar |commentsRishi Sunak delivered his Spring Statement today against a backdrop of darkening economic skies. Families across the country are worried about rising food and fuel costs, soaring inflation and rocketing energy bills. A bold Chancellor would have seized this opportunity to deliver a new economic deal for the British people. Instead we got some tinkering with the tax system and a promise of more support further down the line. When families needed shelter from the economic downpour, the Chancellor offered the equivalent of raising a cocktail umbrella in the middle of a hurricane. Almost all the indicators on the economic dashboard are flashing red.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section Growth forecasts have been slashed, inflation is set to rise to a -year high and the country is set for the biggest fall in living standards since . What support Mr Sunak did provide was either too paltry to make a signicant dference, such as the cut in fuel duty, or a piece of fiscal sleight of hand. Nothing The raising of the National Insurance threshold and the promised cut in income tax will not compensate for the tax hikes coming into force next month. Overall, the tax burden is set to rise to its highest level since the Second World War. Mr Sunak’s claim to be a low-tax Chancellor is as absurd as his claim he was “standing by” families during the cost-of-living crisis. Get the stories you want straight to your inbox.toone of the Mirroraposs newslettersThere was no extra support to help people with energy bills even though they are set to increase by £, on average by this autumn. And there was nothing to help pensioners, the very low-paid and those on social security. Mr Sunak is condemning more people to poverty and more people to choose between heating and eating. Despite Conservative claims that the age of austerity is over, our public services will now receive less funding than originally announced. There will be less money for health, for schools, councils, and the armed forces. People looked to the Chancellor yesterday for help and reassurance. He delivered a financial statement that leaves only anxiety and trepidation. title: roughly 13m brits thousands kids
story: .MILLION Brits set to be dragged into absolute poverty in Spring Statement disasterThe Resolution Foundation think tank said the typical working age household will see their real income fall % next year, casting millions into absolute poverty including , kidsAmong those to fall into absolute poverty next year will be half a million children, says the think tank Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments.milion Brits including half a million children will be dragged below the poverty line despite Rishi Sunak‘s Spring Statement, devastating analysis says. A typical working-age household will see their real income fall % next year - a loss of £,, the Resolution Foundation think tank said. Absolute poverty - rather than relative poverty - is crucial because it is the measure Boris Johnson chooses to use.In  the PM controversially boasted poverty had fallen when relative poverty was up and absolute poverty was down. It comes after the Budget watchdog said soaring inflation - expected to nudge % in a four-decade high - will inflict the biggest disposable income drop since records began in the s. And today the Foundation warned poorer Brits will be hit harder as the Tory Chancellor refused to raise benefits - which will rise at less than half inflation. Meanwhile his £bn in cuts to National Insurance and fuel duty will mostly benefit people in work.Even with a p cut in income tax from , seven out of eight workers will still be paying more tax overall by , the overnight analysis found.The experts said: “The scale and distribution of the cost of living squeeze, coupled with the lack of support for low-income families, means that a further . million people are set to fall into absolute poverty next year, including , children – the first time Britain has seen such a rise outside of recessions.” With UK inflation soaring to .% - its fastest rise in  years - millions of households will be worrying about their own finances. The  cost of living crisis is hitting energy prices, fuel and the cost of food, with the governmentaposs only solution so far to offer all households a £ loan to help pay off their energy bills - which must be paid back eventually. Chancellor Rishi Sunakaposs Spring Statement saw him announce a cut in fuel duty, although this will cost the Treasury billions without putting cash back in familiesapos pockets. So how will the Spring Statement affect you The  huge big cost of living blows hitting you from next Friday What the fuel duty cut actually means - and whether weaposll see the dference in our pockets The Spring Statement  summaryaposs key announcements Everything you need to know about the National Insurance cut The UKaposs current inflation rate amid the Spring Statement - as Brits are left with crippling costsKeep up with live announcements from the Statement in the Mirroraposs live blogIf you need help with the cost of living crisis, weaposve put together a list of charities and schemes offering advice and grants to keep you and your family warm and fed this year. Despite the tax cuts yesterday, the think tank said only those earning between £, and £, will actually pay less income tax in -. And only those earning between £, and £, will pay less tax and National Insurance . Of the  million people in work, around  millionwill pay more in income tax and NI in -, the think tank said. By  earnings will be £, behind what they would have beenthey had continued growing on the pre- path.  Torsten Bell, Chief Executive of the Resolution Foundation, said: “In the face of a cost of living crisis that looks set to make this Parliament the worst on record for household incomes, the Chancellor came to the dispatch box yesterday promising support with the cost of living today, and tax cuts tomorrow. Signicant measures were announced on both counts, but the big picture is that policy does not measure up to the rhetoric. “The decision not to target support at those hardest hit by rising prices will leave low-and-middle income households painfully exposed, with . million people, including half a million children, set to fall below the poverty line this coming year. “And despite the eye-catching p cut to income tax, the reality is that the Chancellor’s tax changes mean that seven-in-eight workers will see their tax bills rise. Those tax rises mean the Chancellor is able to point to a swt fiscal consolidation and signicant headroom against his fiscal rules. “The big picture is that Rishi Sunak has prioritised rebuilding his tax-cutting credentials over supporting the low-to-middle income households who will be hardest hit from the surging cost of living, while also leaving himself fiscal flexibility in the years ahead. Whether that will be sustainable in the face of huge income falls to come remains to be seen.”  Office for Budget Responsibility watchdog chairman Richard Hughes said despite the measures announced by Rishi Sunak, people still face an unprecedented fall in living standards. He told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: So in total, they amount to about an £ billion giveaway in this spring statement coming from the Chancellor. That offsets around a third of the overall hit to living standards that people would otherwise have felt had he not taken those measures, so without the Chancellor taking action, people would have felt a % fall in their living standards in the coming  months. That reduces it down to around %, but itaposs still an unprecedented fall in peopleaposs standard of living over the next  months. Mr Hughes also said energy bills are doubling over the course of the year, rising by around % in April and another % in October. title: sadiq khan says london answering
story: Sadiq Khan says London is answering Ukraines call to take to streets in protestMayor of London Sadiq Khan writes in the Mirror about how London is answering Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskys stirring call to take the streets and protest Vladimir Putins evil invasion is watched by Professor Chris Whittyas he speaks to guests at the London Clean Air and Health Summit at Royal College Of Physicians on February ,  in London, England. Mayor of London Sadiq Khan called on health professionals to play a greater role in informing their London patients about the risks of air pollution and how to protect themselves as recommended in the Coroners report following the inquest into the death of nine-year-old Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah. " content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Mayor-Of-London-Holds-Clean-Air-Summit.jpg" width"" "" March in solidarity says Sadiq Khan Image: Getty ImagesopinionBySadiq KhanMayor of London:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsPresident Zelensky of Ukraine has put out a stirring call for people across the world to take to the streets in solidarity. He’s asking for us to come out and make a stand - for Ukraine, for freedom and for peace. Today, we are answering that call in London. We are organising a march through the centre of our great capital, followed by a vigil in Trafalgar Square, where thousands of people will come together to show their support for the Ukrainian people. We want to send an emphatic message to Ukrainians- you are not alone and we condemn Putin’s barbaric aggression. We will never stop raising our voices in support of the struggle for freedom, peace and democracy. Horric war crimes are being committed by the Putin regime, and this unprovoked invasion is causing the biggest refugee crisis in Europe since the Second World War. We have all seen the heart-breaking images of innocent civilians being targeted, apartment blocks burnt out and children clutching their toys as they flee. I’ve been proud of the way people across our country have come forward to help Ukrainians in their hour of need - whether it’s by donating money or offering a home to refugees. Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News Bulletin here  We have a moral duty to help and on Saturdayaposs march we will be saying loud and clear that we stand ready to welcome more Ukrainians with open arms. Refugees will always be welcome in London and given the support they need. That’s why I’m announcing that City Hall will be giving an extra £. million to ensure refugees get access to the vital services they require when they arrive.  Taking to the streets will also be crucial to keeping up the pressure on national governments – helping to ensure they continue to take the necessary action. So far, many international leaders, businesses and people around the world have been united in putting measures in place to support the Ukrainian people and to hold Putin’s regime accountable. One month on - as the war continues to rage and as Russian shells continue to rain down on innocent civilians in Ukrainian cities - we cannot allow our collective resolve to wane. Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section That’s why it’s more important than ever that we make our voices heard – so that we can ensure our government and governments around the world maintain focus, introduce even tougher sanctions and live up to all the promises made to refugees. We begin our solidarity march from Park Lane at pm. I encourage anyone who can to come along and join us as we stand together with Ukraine.Visit www.london.gov.uk events -- london-stands-ukraine-march-and-vigilRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Sadiq KhanWar crimesVolodymyr ZelenskyRussia Ukraine warUkraine" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: sunak accused gaslighting families over
story: Sunak accused of gaslighting families over Britains cost of living crisisChancellor Rishi Sunak also repeatedly refused to rule out a future bid for the Tory leadership in a tense Sky News interview Image: PRU AFP via Getty ImagesByPress AssociationRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Mar |comments Rishi Sunak has been accused of “gaslighting” the country over the cost of living crisis as he repeatedly declined to rule out launching a bid to lead the Conservative Party.The Chancellor has defended the package of measures he announced in his spring statement on Wednesday, after he had been criticised for not going far enough to those facing falling into poverty due to the rising cost of living. But he said he had “always tried to be honest with people”, and said: “I can’t protect them from absolutely everything that we face.” Mr Sunak said he was “anxious” on behalf of the country and said he knew rising financial pressures were “the number one concern that people have right now”. Speaking on Beth Rigby Interviews on Sky News, he said: “Families are struggling with the rising cost of lots of things and that’s why in the spring statement I wanted to make sure that we demonstrated we were on people’s side, and we announced the tax plan that will deliver the biggest net cut taxes, net cut to personal taxes in two years, in quarter of a century taken together.” He said: “Where we can make a dference, we will, and I’m confident that the plan yesterday will do that.”  The Chancellor added: “I think what we’ve done is substantial. If you take together £ billion to help people with energy bills announced last month, the signicant tax cuts that we announced yesterday, they will all help. But of course they can’t mitigate all the dficulties that high inflation is causing. No chancellor could do that.”Earlier, Downing Street said ministers stood ready to provide further support to householdsrequired after Prime Minister Boris Johnson appeared to suggest more measures could be announced.Mr Johnson admitted it was “going to be tough” as households had to cope with rising prices and the cost-of-living squeeze. He said: “It will continue to be tough, continue to be choppy but we will get through it and we will look after people throughout.” Separately, he told LBC “as we go forward, we need to do more” and insisted the Government would “fix” the rising cost of living.Richard Hughes, chairman of the Office for Budget Responsibility, said on Thursday that despite the measures announced by Mr Sunak, people still face an “unprecedented” fall in living standards.The Institute for Fiscal Studiessaid the Chancellor had failed to protect the country’s poorest households. But Mr Sunak insisted he had “protected those on the lowest incomes the most” in recent years.  Asked about figures from the Resolution Foundation think tank, which said . million Britons were set to fall below the poverty line next year, including , children, Mr Sunak told Beth Rigby Interviews: “Well, I mean, what we do know is the track record, because there’s lots of projections and speculation about the future, but the track record shows that over the last  years, since we’ve had Conservative governments in charge, the number of people living in poverty has actually declined by about . million people. “That includes , children from memory. So actually, that’s a record that I’m proud of. “Now, obviously, a lot of that happened before I was in post. But the actions I’ve taken over the past couple of years have ensured that we have protected those on the lowest incomes the most.” Told that it felt like the country was being “gaslighted” by his reassurances amid the rising costs and as inflation rose, he said: “I’m not denying for one second that inflation is dficult. Of course it’s dficult, and it’s most dficult for those on lower incomes.” The Chancellor, who has been tipped as a potential successor to the PM, also failed three times to rule out that he could launch a leadership bid in the future. He read a quote from Mr Johnson, who said in  that being prime minister “would be a great, great thing to have a crack at”,“the ball came loose from the back of the scrum”, and askedhe felt the same. Mr Sunak said: “I’m much more a cricket and football fan, so I don’t know what the appropriate analogy is. But as we’ve talked about at the moment, there’s a lot going on, there’s a big job to do and I’m fully focused on doing that job and trying to do it as well as I can.” Asked again, with a cricket analogy,he would be interested, he said: “At this point, I’m just trying to stay at the crease and keep in place and not get out.” Asked a third time, this time with a football comparison, he said: “We’re stretching these analogies too far.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyRichard HughesBoris JohnsonEnergy billsLiving standardsPrice risesPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dog who loves cuddles needs
story: Dog who loves cuddles needs new home after being kicked out by ownersTen-year-old Sophia was likely abandoned by her owners after developing a massive hernia - but has been given a second chance at le thanks to Blind Dog Rescue UKSophia is a -year-old crossbreed Image: Blind Dog Rescue UKByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsDespite being cast aside by her owners after developing a painful condition, little Sophia just wants to cuddle up with somebody who isnapost going to hurt her.The -year-old dog has spent months living with a foster family in Nottinghamshire after being rescued from the streets of Romania by Blind Dog Rescue UK.The crossbreed has been described as a real cuddle monster who loves spending time with humans, despite having been subjected to the worst of humanity. A spokeswoman at Blind Dog Rescue UK said: She would be happy beside you, on you and snuggled up on the bed too.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. It is believed she was a dog with a home before but probably thrown out once she developed the massive hernia that has been sorted now. The old girl, who will happily overeatallowed, could do with dropping a few pounds in her new home. She’s house trained and very comfortable in the house with house noises and activities, the spokeswoman added. Despite being an older girl she enjoys play and has a good turn of speed in the garden, she’s fine on the lead. She’s good with dogs, fine with confident cats that will stand their ground. When describing her perfect home, she added: Sophia would love a home with a garden and can live with another or confident cat for company.  Blind Dog Rescue UK works to rehome blind and partially sighted dogs who have been subjected to the “worst of humanity yet still have an astonishing capacity to adapt, love and become perfect ambassadors for blind dogs everywhere”. Many of the dogs in their care have been victims of abuse, neglect, disease or trauma - and struggle to survive in shelters. A Blind Dog Rescue UK statement reads: “It is incredibly dficult for sighted dogs to survive anyof time in these shelters let alone blind or partially sighted dogs. “We need to get to these dogs quickly and secure their immediate release and treatment.  “These dogs may have been deliberately blinded, involved in road traffic accidents or long term sufferers of painful conditions such as glaucoma.“They need veterinary care and to be given the safety and comfort of a foster home in which to start healing. “Here they are given love and affection and a warm bed - possibly the first they will have experienced in their letimes. At this point, we are able to start assessing and promoting these wonderful dogs for forever homes.To adopt Sophia, or any other animals in Blind Dog Rescue UKaposs care, contact their team via their website www.bdruk.org.Do you have a story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsDogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: beloved drag queen lgbtq advocate
story: Beloved drag queen and LGBTQ advocate who always shone bright dies aged Martin Greenfield, AKA Honey Lingus, is thought to have been one of the first black drag queens performing in Newcastle when they started their act in the sMartin Greenfield, who performed as Honey Lingus Image: Mark StephensonByHannah GrahamAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar Friends and family of a beloved drag queen who was a fierce advocate for LGBTQ rights have told of how they “radiated warmth” to everyone they met. Heartfelt tributes have been paid to Martin Greenfield, who performed as “Honey Lingus”.Martin died at the age of  last week, after a struggle with illness and some mental health issues,Chronicle Live reports .As both Martin and Honey, they were much-loved as a performer and a friend, who will be remembered for their energy, light, joy, empathy. Trailblazing Martin is thought to have been one of the first black drag queens performing in Newcastle when they started their act in the s.  Close friend Mark Stephenson remembered them as a star that always shined bright. Mark has known Martin since they were both , when Martin moved to the North East from Hong Kong. The pair worked at popular club Powerhouse together, and Mark recalled how Honey began to come to le as Martin became a part of Newcastleaposs LGBTQ scene. He said: Martin was always bigger than le, very flamboyant, peopleaposs attention was always drawn to Martinaposs clothes and long nails. Back in , , when they started performing as Honey, she was probably one of Newcastleaposs first black drag queens. Martin was a perfectionist so they always looked unreal, absolutely beautul. Honey would work a room and was able to sing brilliantly, could always hold a note, and was very much a perfectionist in terms of being the most beautul person in the room. They did seasons in Ibiza, performing around the world as Honey and they loved that. Honey was really well-known around the gay scene in Newcastle. With a vibrant energy that couldnapost be ignored, Martin loved music and dance and worked with ious cultural organisations across the North East. Mark remembered fondly their love of music - Martin was once dancing so joyfully at a Diana Ross concert in Newcastle that they were invited up on stage - but also the quieter side of Martin, who loved nature, gardening and cooking. Mark said: Thereaposs Honey and thereaposs Martin and they are two dferent people. Honey is Martinaposs bigger-than-le persona. Martin was a very loving person who would give their all to everybody, they were very into growing things and learning new skills, spicing all the food they cooked up to the hilt. That was a dferent side of Martin. A fierce advocate for LGBTQ rights, Martin refused to let prejudice stop them from being themselves. Mark remembers a more hostile environment in the city in the s when Martin started performing, but on or off stage, they refused to be kept silent. He said: Martin was not scared of anything or being the first person to do anything. I remember when we were , walking round Newcastle, and Martin was quite obviously a gay person and people would shout aposp***apos or aposf*****apos and Iaposd be worried, but Martin would just own it, saying aposMark, these people donapost bother meapos. Martin was always very much at the forefront of fighting for what they believed in. I think Martin was someone who paved the path for people and they were definitely someone who did that by being themself, whether as Martin or when performing as Honey. Iaposm just so proud that I had them in my le, because I think my le would very much not have been the sameit wasnapost for Martin. Loved ones are set to say farewell to Martin in a natural burial ceremony and a celebration of their le and their family is currently raising money to commemorate them as they would have wished. On a GoFundMe page which has already collected more than £,, their brother, Steve Greenfield, said: From events with thousands of people down to intimate and real person-to-person conversations, Martinaposs beauty and warmth radiated to everyone. For my part, being sometime witness to the joy they brought, and knowing people in Martin’s many friendship circles, I can say their energy, light, joy, empathy and, at their best, glorious nature will echo, reverberate, and resonate always. Martin was a stunning, unique soul Honey a fierce and compassionate entertainer. Together their force led to a le, though shortened, that was full to the brim with experiences, events, friends and times of truly living. He added: We were all better for knowing Martin or Honey - or indeed both. I have lost a brother, a sister and the person who knew me the best in the entire world.Donations towards the celebrations of Martinaposs le are being collected athttps:www.gofundme f celebrating-martin-honeyRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Mental healthLGBT" data-immediate"data-immediate"The weekly email brings you all the latest news from the LGBTQ+ community plus exclusive interviews direct to your inboxSign UpInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: boy 12 who slept tent
story: Boy, , who has slept in tent every night for two years finally ending camp-outPride of Britain winner Max Woosey, , started his camp out in March  and has since raised a staggering £, which is enough to pay the annual salary of twenty hospice nurses.Max Woosey, , as slept in a tent every night for two years is ending his charity camp-out this weekend - having raised £,ByLiam Buckler:,  Mar |commentsA young boy who has slept in a tent every night for two years is finally ending his charity camp-out this weekend - having raised a whopping £,. This weekend will mark the two-year anniversary since the start Max Woosey, , camped out in March .Since then he has camped out at London Zoo,  Downing Street and Twickenham Rugby Stadium and won praise from PM Boris Johnson.And from March , he has raised a staggering £, - which is more than £, including Gt Aid - enough to pay the annual salary of twenty hospice nurses. Maxaposs Big Camp Out will be on Saturday night where he will be joined by celebrity backers including Carol Vorderman and fellow Pride of Britain winners including Hughie and Freddie, Stephen Wharton and Harmonie-Rose Allen. The event will begin at an undisclosed site in Braunton, Devon, on Saturday at pm and will feature live music throughout the day. Despite drawing the formal fundraising to a close, his mum Rachael Woosey said Max was not coming indoors anytime soon - as camping outside had become a way for le for him.  She said: After the two years passes this weekend, we will become a lot more passive. There will be no need to do social media and we will wind the fund raising down. Max will then quietly do this thing and it will become less about fund raising and more just a way of le. It has been two years of his le that has been amazing and a real adventure for him. But I think he maybe just needs a bit of normality and not have people caring about where he sleeps all the time. But he is not coming in though and wants to stay sleeping in his tent. He said he will consider sleeping in a hotelwe go away but that is his only concession. Heaposs happy out there and there would be more distractions inside. Now heaposs at secondary school, Iaposd just rather he was getting a good nightaposs sleep. The efforts of the inspirational schoolboy has been described as insane by the North Devon Hospice.  The sleep out began on March   in memory of Maxaposs friend and neighbour, Rick Abbot, who died in February . Rick, who was , had given Max a tent and told him to have an adventure with it, so he decided to camp out in the garden of his family home in Braunton. Rachael said Maxaposs longevity had surprised many family members but they were incredibly proud of his achievements. She added: A lot of family members thought enough was enough after six months and there was a big pull to get him back inside. As far as we are concernedhe is in fresh air and sleeping well then we donapost have a problem with it. We are all incredibly proud of what he has done and we love he has done it all off his own back. He has shown children can make a dference and have a go at something. It would have been very easy not to have let him have a go but what he has done has been remarkable. He will be out for the full two years so the last night will be on Monday night. It will be quite emotional and I will camp out with him again that night to finish it off. But that will be a private time for us - the big public event to close it is on Saturday. What he has achieved for the hospice has made such a dference. But as an inidual he has also grown in confidence and that will set him up for the future. He has an amazing sense of self now and will carry that forward I am sure. The support we have had from everyone has been amazing and I would like to thank everyone for really getting behind Max the way they have. To achieve so much by sleeping in his tent has been remarkable really. Reflecting on the last year, which also saw him pick up a Pride of Britain award, Max said: The whole thing has been a bit of a dream. I have met so many amazing people and done so many amazing things such as going to Twickenham and  Downing Street. The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. We recognise the news agenda can sometimes feel overwhelmingly negative.And while itaposs our job to keep you informed and hold those in power to account, we are making a commitment to also report more hopeful news. We will celebrate the people, places and movements that are bringing good into the world and, more than that, we will dig beneath the surface of important issues with the aim of finding hope.We will be firm in our convictions - but always fair-minded. By sharing solutions to problems, we can do more good and feel better about the world around us. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on Facebook I managed to pitch it in London Zoo that was phenomenal and definitely another highlight. It has been incredible and just going to the Pride of Britain was amazing. There has been so many highlights. The tent is now my home and I donapost know how to sleep in bed. I donapost think I would be able to sleep inside now. Max said during the time of his challenge he has slept in  dferent tents. He added: It is just a really nice feeling inside knowing I have helped to raise so much money. I am just really thankful for everyone who has donated. The hospice are the real heroes and do all the hard work. North Devon Hospice has said the money equated to almost  nurses working for  months. At the time Max started the challenge the hospice was facing a £m drop in funding because of the lockdown.To donate visit Maxaposs camp out for North Devon Hospice Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Carol VordermanPride of Britain AwardsCharitiesEducationZoosSecondary schoolMirror More Hopeful" data-immediate"data-immediate"Our Pride of Britain newsletter brings you awards news and inspiring stories - dont miss out!Sign me upInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: brits health conditions told stay
story: Brits with health conditions told to stay indoors as rise in pollution puts them at riskAdvice issued by DEFRA suggests adults and children with lung problems, and adults with heart problems, should reduce strenuous physical exertion, particularly outdoorsPeople enjoy a day out at Primrose Hill on a particularly smoggy day Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsBrits with health conditions are being urged to stay indoors, as a rise in pollution levels puts them at risk. High air pollution warnings have been issued for parts of England, such as the Midlands, the South East, and North West. The high alert is in place from London to Ipswich and Cambridge, as well as further north to Nottingham and to Hull. According to the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs , Leicester, Northampton, and Manchester are also among the places affected, along with spots along the south coast, including Brighton, Eastbourne and Hastings. Advice issued by DEFRA suggests adults and children with lung problems, and adults with heart problems, should “reduce strenuous physical exertion, particularly outdoors, and particularlythey experience symptoms”. “People with asthma may find they need to use their reliever inhaler more often.  “Older people should also reduce physical exertion,” the group added.Additionally, anyone experiencing discomfort such as sore eyes, cough or sore throat was advised to consider reducing activity, particularly outdoors. According to Sky News, Mayor of London Sadiq Khan warned that toxic air “is dangerous”, particularly for those with heart and lung problems.He urged residents to look after each other by walking, cycling, avoiding unnecessary car trips and stopping engine idling. He also asked people to withhold from burning wood or garden waste. Earlier this year Mr Khan said car use had ed to close to pre-pandemic levels and that the effect on residents could be disastrous.“If we do not double down on our efforts to deliver a greener, more sustainable future, we will replace one public health crisis with another – caused by filthy air and gridlocked roads,” he said. In January, a candlelit-vigil was held in south London by the mother of Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah on what would have been her th birthday. She died in  aged just nine-years-old following an asthma attack. In December , she became the first person in the UK to have air pollution listed as a cause of death after a second landmark inquest. Southwark Coroneraposs Court found that air pollution made a material contribution to Ellaaposs death. She lived with her her family close to the South Circular Road in Lewisham, south-east London Prof Gavin Shaddick, a government adviser on air pollution, called it a landmark decision. According to a survey by Kleenex, two thirds of hayfever sufferers believe pollution is the biggest factor that affects their allergies. title: canoe man john darwin almost
story: Exclusive: Canoe man John Darwin almost killed himself for REAL in bid to fake his deathFraudster John Darwin wrote his memoirs while in jail for a £, le insurance fraud - he revealed he actually nearly did kill himself for real without meaning to when he pretended to vanish in his kayakBack home - Darwin in Seaton Carew in  after his release Image: Daily MirrorByJeremy ArmstrongNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsCanoe man John Darwin almost killed himself as he faked his death at sea, his memoirs have revealed.The fraudster wrote his story while in jail for the £, le insurance fraud. Ex-teacher and prison officer Darwin, now , sparked a huge search in  after he “vanished” in his kayak. He lived as a “dead man’” for five years with we Anne, , first in a room hidden by a wardrobe. In his unpublished memoir, seen by the Mirror, he tells of the day he put to sea near his home in Seaton Carew, Co Durham. He writes: “I started to paddle again, heading towards the pier which I had spotted a few minutes earlier.  “It then struck me that I couldn’t see the South Gare [breakwater at the mouth of the River Tees]. “I’d actually paddled out much, much further than I intended. To my total horror, I realised I could have been swept away and died. I had nearly done it without meaning to.” Darwin, who spent two-and-a-half years behind bars for fraud, still kayaks off the Philippines where he now lives with second we Mercy May, .  Get the stories you want straight to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newslettersHe loves to head out in the summer to escape the crowded streets of the capital Manila. Earlier this week we reported Mercy’s bizarre claim that her husband wants to fight in Ukraine, despite his age.He and Anne ­­­orced after  years while both were in jail. She has since rebuilt her relationship with sons Mark and Anthony, who she lied to about their dad’s “death”.  The astonishing story is to be told next month in a four-part ITV dramatisation The Thief, His We and The Canoe starring Eddie Marsan and Monica Dolan.The series was inspired by a book by former Daily Mirror journalist David Leigh, who found Anne in Panama after John ed to the UK in . title: dad says life never same
story: Dad says le will never be the same after daughter and we die just two years apartFred Woolerton, , tragically lost his daughter, Alexis May Woolerton, aged just , on Christmas Eve , and his we, Anne-Marie, died two years later after being diagnosed with lung cancerFred is representing local cancer charity Maggies in his bright orange kit and has his we and daughters names printed on his bike Image: MEN MEDIAByLucy MarshallLiam Buckler:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA dad who tragically lost his we and daughter to cancer in the space of two years has said le will never be the same for him. Fred Woolerton, , had his le turned upside down when his daughter, Alexis May Woolerton, died on Christmas Eve , in Overgate Hospice after battling cancer aged just . After the devastating lost shook him, he and we Anne-Marie were never the same.As a result, he lost his taste and smell, and said no parent should have to see their child die, he told LeedsLive.Tragically, just two years later we Anne-Marie was diagnosed with lung cancer which sadly spread to her pancreas before reaching her brain. The couple loved going on holiday to Benidorm together, and Anne-Marie loved playing Candy Crush and doing everything for her husband. However after undergoing tireless amounts of treatment, Anne-Marie died on April  . After she was gone I was never the same, Fred admitted. To support Fredaposs challenge click here to donate.  The -year-old granddad felt naturally lost and unmotivated about le. However, he admitted he a good support system around him which has enabled him to get through the dficult times. Fred said: Death creates such an entity behind you. Youaposre in a dark place one minute and then you the other way. You take five steps forward, and then  back. People say that time is a healer but I think while it helps, the key is to have a good structure around you. When people say they understand itaposs nice to say but they donapost understand. I donapost go out half as much now I think sometimes I feel like a burden because people think they canapost have a good time because Iaposm there. Le has got to go on though. Itaposs not fair for me to put that on people. Fred luckily has a number of friends in the community. One vital friend is Adele Kendrew who helps run the Edmund House social club in Pontefract Lane.  She told Fred she would help him get back on his feet by keeping him busy day to day. He began cleaning, painting, and helping sorting out the club which gave him a sense of purpose. Fred added: It helped me come out of my shell and gave me a sense of purpose. It took my mind off it. Itaposs like youaposre acting on a stage and then you come off stage and you have to face reality when you go home. It would all come back to me then. But the club did their absolute best and it did help. People might not think it but Iaposm such a reserved person and itaposs hard to talk about a subject that has taken two members of your family. He wanted to help out his community and give back to families struck down by cancer and he began helping out with Leeds independent charity Maggieaposs. Fred added: Maggieaposs has been open short of three years and I went in and I broke down. Theyaposre really good understanding people. I ask themI could help out, and while they told me itaposs not for everybody I am now able to help people feel comforted, and I speak to them about the hard times. The charity decided to conduct a charity bike ride from Leeds to Barcelona - covering , miles. Fred immediately signed up and will be taking part in the challenge on April  - coincidentally the anniversary of his weaposs death. He said: The date of the bike ride is the day of my weaposs death. Iaposve had my bike sprayed and the colours are the same as the Maggieaposs logo. My bike has both my we and daughteraposs name on. I look at le like a crusade now, not just for me, but I am doing this for everybody and for people who canapost do it. Although since having a knee replacement recently, the brave granddad will travel from Leeds, through to Hull, ferry to Rotterdam, Belgium into France and then ride down into Barcelona through Spain. Fred added: I have seen the dference Maggieaposs makes in peopleaposs lives, and I know it is essential that these centres and charities help support those with cancer and their families. This fundraiser is to help sponsor myself regarding this bike ride, supporting Maggieaposs charity and all of the hard work they do for those who have cancer and the consequences it leaves behind.To support Fredaposs challenge click here to donate.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Cancer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: horror film moment mum watched
story: Exclusive: Horror film moment mum watched -year-old daughters face drop during severe strokeVictoria Fisher was just five years old when she was left with a third of her brain damaged after she collapsed at school with a stroke before experiencing a second one in hospitalVictoria was just  when she collapsed at school and was unable to smile or le her both arms above her head Image: Laura HindleByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A schoolgirl who was left partially paralysed after she suffered two strokes at the age of five is now asking strangers to help her regain independence.Victoria Fisher, from South Croydon, London, was a fit and healthy little girl when she suddenly collapsed at school and was unable to use one side of her body in November . Her mum, Laura Hindle, , watched in disbelief as she was rushed to hospital where she suffered a second stroke, leaving a third of her brain damaged and paralysing the left side of her body. Now eight years old, Victoria still suffers with hemiplegia , causing extreme fatigue and dficulty completing certain tasks.Stay at home mum, Laura told The Mirror : “I still to this day cannot get my head around it, it’s horric. “I had received a call from her school to say that she had taken a bit of a tumble in the playground but she was fine, so I said ‘thanks for letting me know’ and didn’t worry too much. “But then a couple of hours later I got another call to say she was very ill and I needed to come right away because they had called her an ambulance. “When I got there she had completely collapsed, she was just slumped up against one side of the room. She couldn’t talk to me or anything. “When the paramedics got there they asked her to put her hands above her head, but she could only lt her right arm.“Then they asked her to smile and there was a visible drop on one side. “For a split second it crossed my mind ‘she’s had a stroke’. “But then I told myself don’t be ridiculous, children don’t have strokes.” Victoria was rushed to hospital where tests confirmed Laura’s worst fears - she had experienced a stroke, but doctors were unable to determine any trigger or cause. Only the following day, while waiting for a scan with her parents in the hospital, Victoria experienced a second severe stroke, leaving her left side paralysed and damaging  per cent of her brain. Mum of four Laura said: “We were walking down the corridor and she turned around and said ‘my headache is coming back’. “Just as she put her hand to her head, she collapsed. “I had never heard of a child having a stroke, I was in shock, we couldn’t get to grips with what the doctors were talking about until they showed us her scans and we saw the damage. “To actually witness my child’s face visibly dropping on one side was horric, it was like something out of a horror film.” After extensive research, Laura has discovered a machine which would give Victoria the use of her arm again, by stimulating the nerves which send messages to the limb from the brain.Victoria has already benefited from temporary use of the Saebo-stimulator Pro machine in the weeks after her strokes while recovering at The Children’s Trust for children with brain injuries. But now Laura is desperate to give her daughter a “normal le” after admitting that some children have already started teasing Victoria for her injury.Now Laura has set up a GoFundMe to raise £, for the machine and therapy to help Victoria, with any proceeds spent on further rehabilitation which could aid a normal lestyle.She said: “People that don’t know Victoria might just think that she has had an injury because of her walk. “But she experiences extreme fatigue and she has a tendency to fall over a lot. “She’s already had some grief from other kids being unkind saying things like ‘you can’t play with us because you only have one arm’. “It’s dficult because children often don’t understand things they can’t see and a stroke is something you can’t see.“It’s heartbreaking to watch her sometimes because she wants so badly to be able to do something as simple as remove a pen lid without having to ask someone to do it for her, or putting her school tie on. “She’s such a bright and bubbly little girl, she loves dancing and playing just like any other child her age. “I want her to have access to everything anyone can expect from a normal le like being able to do her makeup when she gets older. “I always tell her, you’re no dferent to anybody , you just need a bit more time.”To donate to Victoria’s fundraiser, click here.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON StrokeHospitalsTherapy" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ikea sincerely sorry after bosses
story: IKEA sincerely sorry after bosses inadvertently film staff using bathrooms at workThe mix-up came about after bosses installed cameras in toilet ceiling voids in November  to monitor staff members alleged drug use and provision of  urine samplesIKEA inadvertently filmed staff using bathrooms at work with cameras installed to monitor staffs alleged drug use Image: Manchester Evening NewsByBen TurnerAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsIKEA has apologised after bosses inadvertently filmed staff using bathrooms at work after they installed CCTV above the toilets. The furniture giant today published findings of a probe into surveillance cameras placed above  bathrooms at a distribution centre in Peterborough. Bosses installed cameras in toilet ceiling voids in November  to monitor staff membersapos alleged drug use and provision of  urine samples. But the investigation revealed that two cameras became dislodged and accidentally filmed communal areas in both a female and male bathroom. No footage was captured of toilet cubicles. An IKEA spokesperson said: Whilst the intention at the time was to ensure the health and safety of co-workers, we understand the fact that colleagues were filmed unknowingly in these circumstances will have caused real concern.  ‘For this we are sincerely sorry,” they continued. The cameras were operational until July  and were not recording when staff found them last September, the investigation said. It added that no CCTV was recorded in toilet cubicles and that footage showing staff in bathrooms was only seen during the independent investigation. An IKEA spokesperson added: Their [the camerasapos] installation followed serious concerns about the use of drugs onsite, which, owing to the nature of work carried out at the site, could have very serious consequences for the safety of our co-workers. The cameras placed within the voids were positioned only to record irregular activity in the ceiling voids. They were not intended to, and did not, record footage in the toilet cubicles themselves. “However, as a result of ceiling tiles becoming dislodged, two cameras inadvertently recorded footage of the communal areas of two bathrooms for a period of time in . The footage was not viewed at the time and was only recovered as part of these investigations. IKEA said it had passed the reportaposs findings onto the Information Commissioneraposs Office, the UK regulator for data privacy. news uk-news joe-biden-scoffs-pizza-troops-"Joe Biden eats pizza with service members in PolandByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsUS President Joe Biden was snapped chomping down on pizza with US troops near the Ukrainian border.The th President landed in Rzeszow, Poland today to take stock of how Ukrainian refugees have been helped and to speak to his troops at NATOapos s eastern flank.His stop was to meet with soldiers from the U.S. Armyaposs nd Airborne Division stationed near the airport where he stopped to have a bite. TV footage showed him scoffing down a pepperoni pizza and chatting with several military personnel. Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News Bulletin here But Biden complained he was blocked from crossing the border to Ukraine.In an emotional speech, he also mentioned his grandfather and his late son Beau Biden who was an Iraq War veteran. Like you, he didnapost have to go either... the point is there are hundreds of thousands of people like my son, like all of you, so thank you. Thank you, thank you, thank you, he said. We have a sacred obligation in this government... to equip those we send to war and to care for them and their families when they come home, he said.  It comes as Biden was due to be briefed on the humanitarian response to help civilians sheltering from Russian attacks inside Ukraine and to respond to the growing flow of refugees fleeing Ukraine. Biden told reporters in Brussels yesterday that his visit to Poland will reinforce my commitment to have the United States make sure we are a major piece of dealing with the relocation of all those folks, as well as humanitarian assistance needed both inside Ukraine and outside Ukraine. The US President is due to travel to Warsaw to have talks with Polandaposs President Andrzej Duda. National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan appeared to the United States and its allies could still impose new measures to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.During an emergency NATO summit in Brussels yesterday, leaders agreed to step up measures to protect Ukraine and members of the -country alliance from a Russian chemical or nuclear attack. Secretary-general Jens Stoltenberg told reporters in Brussels: Today we agreed to do more including cyber-security assistance and equipment to help Ukraine protect against biological, chemical, radiological and nuclear threats. This could include detection equipment, protection and medical supplies, as well as training for decontamination and crisis management. Mr Stoltenberg said Natoaposs chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear defence elements had been activated and we are taking measures both to support Ukraine and to defend ourselves. Asked whether the move was based on credible intelligence, Mr Stoltenberg said: We are concerned, partly because we see the rhetoric and we see that Russia is trying to create some kind of pretext - accusing Ukraine, the United States, Nato allies - for preparing to use chemical and biological weapons. Earlier Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urged NATO chiefs to send tanks and warplanes to his war-torn country so forces can repel Russian invaders.In a passionate video link plea to an emergency summit at the coalition’s headquarters, he warned leaders from the organisation’s  member countries that delays to vital equipment were costing lives. He fumed: “You have thousands of fighter jets but we havenapost been given any yet. “We asked for tanks so that we can unblock our cities that are now dying - Mariupol, Berdyansk, Melitopol, others - cities where Russia is keeping hundreds of thousands of people hostage and articially creating famine no water, no food, nothing there. “You have at least , tanks Ukraine asked for a per cent - one per cent of all your tanks to be given or sold to us - but we do not have a clear answer yet. “The worst thing during the war is not having clear answers to requests for help.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NatoU.S. ArmyJens StoltenbergJoe BidenNATO summitSoldiersPizzaOn Instagram" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news my-epilepsy-misdiagnosed-over--"How epilepsy can change your leByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Mar |commentsFor more than four years, Rachel Wilsonaposs epilepsy was misdiagnosed as sinus problems, an allergy and then anxiety.The mum-of-one thought she must be going crazy as doctors repeatedly failed to address her symptoms. Rachel Wilson, from St Helens, had to stop driving and leave her job - but still had no idea what was wrong with her. Medical officials repeatedly told her that her symptoms were just anxiety - leaving Rachel fearing that she was going aposcrazyapos. Eventually, she issued a desperate plea on Facebook, asking friends and family for help identying her symptoms. Incredibly, a chance conversation with a friend who saw her post led the mum to discover she had epilepsy. Speaking to the Mirror, she recalled the first time she suffered a seizure - while driving with her son Sonny. She said: It was completely out of the blue, I was driving to Manchester with my little boy in the car.Luckily, we were in traffic lights, and I just had this with a weird sensation.Almost like I was going to faint and I opened the windows. It was really strange.On the way home, I had another one and we were on the motorway and I was completely paralysed, I couldnapost even indicate for the junction we needed to get off at. I was having them every time, while I was working. I couldnapost put my finger on it. After visiting the doctors, she was diagnosed with sinusitis and underwent surgery which made no dference and then sent for allergy testing. But when the pandemic struck - she struggled to access help, and her mental health noseed. She said: I was misdiagnosed for a long time, and due to the prolonged misdiagnosis, I was made to feel like it was psychological. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter hereAt times, I felt like I was going crazy. In the beginning, my symptoms werenapost taken seriously. I wasn’t sent for any tests and so the diagnosis was delayed.I was given other diagnoses that were minor in comparison to epilepsy, ones which required a lot less investigation. My seizures were put down to sinus problems, an allergy and then anxiety.I was placed on a lot of antidepressants and anti-anxiety medications and told that once the depression eased, then the aposanxiety attacksapos which were actually seizures would also settle down.The GP never referred me to anyone . During the pandemic, she struggled further as she was never offered a video or virtual appointment.Rachel said: For a long time, the seizures were described as aposa classic case of anxiety attacksapos due to a mental and nervous breakdown…that I had suffered  years after starting with the seizures.It was only when I spoke to a dferent GP that she was concerned and sent me to AE. This was after four and a half years of seizures.I was diagnosed in December  with epilepsy and frontal lobe cavernoma. I was absolutely devastated I couldnapost see any future with such a lelong diagnosis.I felt angry that this had happened to me, I felt desperately sad. I felt guilty, that I had failed my family, that I wasnapost the woman that my husband had married and that neither of us had signed up to this.I was worried that le would never be the same and that my son deserved more than me as his Mama. I was angry that this could have been diagnosed a long time ago and that by now I would have accepted and come to terms with it. I worried about finances, too. I had recently lost my job due to ill health and then I knew I’d have to surrender my driving licence. I knew it would really dficult for my husband to stay in the same job role.I worried about having to rely on other people to do things for me, things that I once seemingly took for granted. I had heard of epilepsy, but it turns out I knew very little. I had a preconception that all seizures were physical and that it was always caused by flashing lights.When I was diagnosed, I realised that flashing lights affect a minority and that the term ‘invisible disabilities’ now applies to me. I have absence seizures. I get an aura of a rising in my stomach, almost like Iaposm on a fairground ride. It’s a rising burning sensation from my stomach to my chest.I usually have time to say aposIaposm having a feelingapos until I go into the seizure. I have always called them aposfeelingsapos because for over  years I didnapost know what they were and how to describe them to my young son.It was important for him to be aware that they were happening, and calling them feelings didnapost sound as scary for him. Once the aura is over, I quickly go into a zoned-out state.I am completely paralysed and unable to move any part of my body, including blinking. I have been told I have a certain vacant look. I stare into space and Iaposm not able to communicate. Everything around me is intensied, noises sound unbearably loud, voices sound distorted, I become really cold with goosebumps. This lasts for approximately  minutes, and then I become really hot, sweating and Iaposm wiped out and exhausted. The more I have the more tired I am.I can fall asleep suddenly and usually by the time it passes I then have another one quickly after. We have all been shocked. I have felt supported. I have found that with a diagnosis, people have been a lot more accepting of what have turned out to be seizures.No-one knows what another person is going through, but people have a lot of love and support to give. Since diagnosis, it feels amazing to have people listen, believe and understand what I have been feeling for so long.The worries and lack of understanding on my part impacted my mental health. I am currently under a neurologist and a neurosurgeon for the cavernoma.Now she hasnapost had a seizure since th January, after starting medication, and says she is starting to remember the person I was before this started and I see light at the end of tunnel.” As many as , people in the UK are facing an epilepsy diagnosis this year, but Epilepsy Action warns many are struggling to get the information they need. Tom Beddow, advice and information services manager at Epilepsy Action, said: “The impact of epilepsy is huge, and goes way beyond initial diagnosis.Even before the pandemic hit, neurology services were one of the least funded, most stretched areas of the NHS.“Now, two years on, we have a surge in people seeking our help, fresh from being diagnosed over the phone, sometimes in as little as  minutes.Many are being left to their own devices, struggling to find support, not knowing their rights or their rrisks.To coincide with Purple Day on  March, the global awareness day for epilepsy, Epilepsy Action has released a video sharing the overwhelming panic and confusion that can follow an epilepsy diagnosis. If you are looking for support, visit epilepsy.org.uk or by calling the Epilepsy Action helpline on freephone   . title: one speed camera snares 815
story: One speed camera snares  holidaymakers - including one motorist twice in one dayAn infamous speed camera on the A between Abergwyngregyn and Talybont, Gwynedd, in Wales, has left one man so angry hes warned motorists not to drive down the road or risk being finedMotorists are being warned of a speed trap which as caught  drivers speeding over six weekends Image: Hadyn Iball   North Wales LiveByAndrew ForgraveSean McPolin:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsMotorists are being warned of a notorious speed trap which as caught  drivers speeding over the course of six weekends - including one man twice. The now-infamous bit of road has left many people red-faced and a few quid down while travelling from England to North Wales on holiday. The stretch on the A between Abergwyngregyn and Talybont, Gwynedd, in Wales, has left one driver so incensed he urged people not to drive down it unless theyaposre aware of the speed restrictions.One motorist Anthony Martindale penned a letter in frustration to the Liverpool Echo, the Daily Post reports.Mr Martindale was caught speeding in both directions between junctions  and , even though all lanes were open and no construction work was being carried out - earning himself a £ fine, three points on his licence and ordered to take a drivers awareness course costing £.  He said: The construction workers had made sure everything was safe when they stopped work on the Friday evening, so health and safety was not an issue.“All four lanes were open so there was no disruption to traffic. Yet the North Wales Police still saw fit to continue letting the traffic continue at mph when it was safe to resume the statutory speed of mph.“On the westbound, I was caught doing mph and on the eastbound I was doing mph. It seems I was not alone thinking that it was actually safer to travel faster on that stretch of road because on that particular Sunday,  people were caught, myself included.” Temporary speeding restrictions are in place along the road as part of a £m scheme to improve safety along part of the .km stretch of carriageway.  Access roads are being removed and eight gaps in the central reservation are being plugged, while a new parallel road, with underpass, is being built for farm vehicles. Mr Martindaleaposs expensive trip prompted a Freedom of Information request to police which showed over six weekend - from January  to February  - a total of  speeding fines were handed out between junctions  and . On January , the worst day for speeding drivers,  were dished out, with numbers tailing off after that. On the weekend from February  to February , no fines were handed out - but only as all temporary signs were removed after a severe weather warning.Worst day for fines was on January  when  fines were awarded. Thereafter, motorists became wiser to the restrictions and the number of fines tailed off. On the weekend of February -, no fines were dished out – but only because all temporary signs were removed after a severe weather warning. Mr Martindale wants to warn holidaymakers to be aware of suffering the same consequences he did. He said: “If any readers are planning to go to North Wales over the summer months, they need to be made aware that at the roadworks on the A at junction  and , anyone going faster than mph will be photographed and fined.” On this stretch of the road, a Temporary Traffic Order restricts speeds to mph through the works. A mph speed limit is also in place on the approaches to the works. These restrictions are operational  hours-a-day. A Welsh Government spokesman said: “Narrow lanes and a mph speed restriction were implemented on the eastbound carriageway during March  and on the westbound carriageway during October . These restrictions were introduced to protect both the travelling public and the workforce.
